Add to that decent zombie make-up and a random storyline about a mad scientist mutating humans in a jungle lab and you've got a great midnight movie.I enjoyed House of the Dead a lot. It alleviated the boredom of a rainy Saturday, it's silly, over the top and full of guns and zombies. Still, Citizen Kane it ain't. The first half-hour drags in a way only STVs manage, i.e. nothing happens, in a very boring fashion, except for a few girls getting their twins out, which is normally not much to shout about with these casts anyway. Once the last 30 or 40 minutes are on, it's rubber-suited zombie ass-kicking all the way, but there could be a problem with that. Uwe Boll's direction is a GIANT HUGE sticking point with many people, and I can see why on viewing this. In-game footage of zombie attacks is edited into the live footage and whenever a key character dies instead of getting a zombie-nosh death scene, it cuts to a weird spinning camera shot of the character, like a 'Game Over' screen. It's a strange way of building in the video-game heritage, and it's often as annoying than it is inventive.Continuity is also a word that's obviously not in this movie's dictionary. I'm not talking 'hey, how the hell did Jason manage to get over there so fast' continuity errors, I'm talking 'I pointed two guns at the screen but when it cut to me shooting you I blew you away with a Shotgun'. Another thing that gave me some jip was a scene where a character comments on someone's choice of zombie-masher 'Hmm, Desert Eagle, nice...' and the character's holding some random prop gun, obviously bought from Toys R Us the night before. It wouldn't have been irritating, but earlier a character shoots some zombies with an ACTUAL Desert Eagle prop, so they had one on-set, why not give the character one and not look daft? Still, labouring on a point there.These movies aren't about how well they're put together, they're about how much fun they are. HotD gets a big thumbs up on that front, and I have to say as STV goes, it's up there with the best of 'em. I haven't seen any other Boll movies, but despite some initial fears, HotD is a hoot. Not a particularly big, clever hoot, but a hoot. If you view this for what it is, a camp, gory low budget zombie-blaster, it's great fun. It won't set your world on fire, but you'll at least be entertained.

reviews.review_title: Ona Grauer is very sexy, and therefore highly appreciated
reviews.content: Ona Grauer makes this flick worth watching; as she's the only woman in the cast who seems to have beautiful tits, though she never uncovers them.The flick is a zombie thriller that excels in maintaining a joyful atmosphere; there's an assured joviality in a flick that replaces the mind with a game console. As in the video-games ,everything is very abstract and artificialthe turning of the young people into zombie killers; the tribulations on the island (the shore; the party site; the house); the deaths of Casper and the smuggler Kirk .As a video game with actors, HOUSE OF THE DEAD is nice; it's stupid and limited, and artificial, but so are the video-games. Everything is imponderable and cool in the phony way of the video-games. Then, why the indignation? HOUSE OF THE DEAD is simply the performed version of a video game. The music, the effects, the fights simply expose what's stupid and phony in a video game.On death's island, a multi-centennial Spanish priest, an enemy of God and people, has created his army of extremely rapid and violent zombies. The zombies did not attack those who have come on the named island to prepare the site for the fancy party; but they attack, even on daylight, the party-goers. There are some verbal hints to the popular culture (the Romero trilogy; a Tolkien character, Kirk and Spock, etc.) .Ona Grauer plays an energetic, strong and lucid character; her cleavage is beautiful.HOUSE OF THE DEAD is an insipid, highly artificial ,hyperkinetic ,deliberately kitsch thriller. I have seen it with some pleasure.Be fairwho might dislike a thriller that, although based on a video game, features a girl with large tits? And those fair tits are quite obvious through her cleavage?A note for the Uwe Boll basheryou punks, go bash Peter Fonda, Frederic Schoendoerffer or other hacks.

This movie has IN GAME footage of the actual house of the dead video game as a sad attempt to a scare it's audience.As opposed to scaring someone it just created this awkward sad atmosphere and really made the audience think how hard and awkward the director's adolescent years must of been for him(Excluding his adult years).When the corny outdated flash of the VIDEO GAME FOOTAGE flashed onto screen, the audience went completely silent. Phone conversations stopped, the child 3 rows in front of me stopped crying. We just sat there...Pondering to ourselves: We PAID to see this?The first group of people walked out hereI held out on wishful thinking that a disgruntled editor slipped that into the final cut. But Oh no.Midway through the film (When i got up and left). My friends and I just felt used and emotionally drained that we managed to stay that long. Somebody really needs to stand up and do something about movies like this. Movie goers shouldn't have to take this anymore. UWE BOLL!! STOP MAKING FILMS FOR THE LOVE OF GOD!! This man needs to return to his pubecent roots of having his head jammed into a toilet, not given millions of dollars of investors money to make ungodly bad films that are in turn unleashed on innocent bystanders.

reviews.review_title: It's crap but a fun piece of trash.
reviews.content: A group of College Kids (Jonathan Cherry, Ona Grauer, William Sanderson, Tyron Leitso, Enuka Okuma, Kira Clavell & Sonya Solomaa) just wants to party during their spring break. They are invited to a rave in a island outside from Seattle. Once they arrived... it's completely deserted but soon they find out, they are not alone. When a group of bloodthirsty zombies comes to kill or eat them alive. Now these group of kids along with a boat captain (Jurgen Prochnow) and a marine police officer (Ellie Cornell) battle the undead to stay alive.Directed by Uwe Boll (Alone in the Dark, BloodRayne, Postal) made an another instant Camp Classic film with plenty of ridiculous humour, first class bad acting but at least... it has some exciting action sequences and good make-up effects. This is one of Boll's most entertaining film along with "Dungenon Siege". Prochnow gives the film's best performance and he seems to be having some fun in the movie but he was unhappy with the script changes during production. Cult B-Movie Actor:Clint Howard appears in a small role as the skipper. This film was an small success in theaters but find itself instead cult audiences on DVD, for those who enjoyed bad movies.DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (1.85:1) transfer and an strong DTS 5.1 Surround Sound (Also in Dolby Digital 5.1). DVD includes two entertaining commentary tracks by the filmmakers. Commentary one is by the director, crew members and actor:Sanderson. The Second Commentary by the Executive Producer/Story/Co-Screenwriter:Mark A. Altman is the most enjoyable to listen. DVD also includes Deleted Scenes, Two Featurettes and more. "House of the Dead" is a enjoyable bad movie but there's one thing... i truly hated in this feature is Boll's use of showing video game footage every couple of minutes or so. It relies too heavily on reminding viewers, we are watching an live-action video game. Since this feature was shot on Super 35, which it was seen in theaters in the 2.35:1 aspect ratio. Probably in the Uwe Boll's new re-cut of "House of the Dead:Funny Version" will might see it in the original 2.35:1 format. Which it's coming out soon on DVD. If you love bad film-making, don't miss this. (*** 1/2 out of *****).

reviews.review_title: I liked it. I've already made an appointment for the lobotomy.
reviews.content: The only review of this one I really read was one on Ain't it Cool news (a site I'm trying to break the habit of visiting) where the guy simply repeated the words "sucked" over and over again.While I kept that in mind as i rented this one, you should keep something else in mind before you read this.1. I love zombie movies. Yes, I'm one of those guys. Zombie films like Dawn of the Dead and Lucio Fulci's Zombie were part of my initial education of the horror genra back in 1997. It's a genra that apart from a few hiccups, had been dormant since the mid-80's.2. And this is the kicker: I actually kind of like movies based off of video games. Well, I should change that too: I'll give movies based off of video games a chance. Maybe it's because I grew up in the age of the original Nintendo (and the age of the Atari, now that I think about it, although I was so young then that I had to ask my dad to hook it up everytime I wanted to play it), but I think it's possible to make a video game based movie as long as the film captures the spirit of the game. It's been done before: Both Tomb Raider films are kind of nifty; Mortal Kombat was fun in a Saturday afternoon way; And Resident Evil was OK, I suppose. But it's also been done really poorly: Wing Commander (does anyone even remember that game?); Double Dragon; Street Fighter all come to mind.So, here we are with House of the Dead, an adaptation of the Sega arcade game (I'm guessing it was available on other platforms, but I'm only familer with the ardade version).It was one of those first person games where the player used a lightgun to fire at zombies and such that lurched towards them. It was pretty cool, I suppose. And did a fairly good job of recreating the vibe of a 70's zombie flick. So, I actually thought it made a lot of sense to make a movie based off of it.The Plot: A handful of young adults get a ferry ride to an island where an allnight rave is being held. They arrive only to find the place deserted, except for the legions of zombies being raised by the spirit of a tortured Spanish scientist from the 14th century or something.Thrown into the mix are a crusty sea smuggler, and an undercover police officer.The first twenty minutes or so of this is more bland than it is bad. But when the zombies start popping up, House of the Dead reaches an apex of sorts in what its trying to do. Let's just say that when the protagonists launch their big offensive against the dead, the story gives way to what seems like nearly 25 minutes of uninterrupted bloody action.Bullets fly, heads go exploding, limbs get munched. All to the tune of a heavy metal song that I actually kind of liked. Well, I didn't like it so much as I thought it fit the scene real well. Maybe it's that part of me that grew up in the era of Iron Maiden and Judas Priest, but it's kind of nice to have heavy metal reclassified as "devil music" instead of "I'm mad at my mommy for bringing home a stepdaddy music."Yes, it's silly. Yes, the constant screen shots from the video game are a bit much. Yes, like i said, the big battle really does occupy nearly a third of the film's running time. All of these criticisms are valid, I suppose.Still, the movie worked for me. 2003 and 2004 found horror coming back to life in a way. New directors were going back to the past for inspiration, and bringing back new takes on old stories. Eli Roth's "Cabin Fever" drew from cyncical portraits of human cruelty like "Last House on the Left." Marcus Nispel's redux of "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" did the same, only with a nearly apocalyptic visual sense. Heck, even the 2004 take of "Dawn of the Dead" showed new audiences a hint of the cerebral horror of George Romero.It's amazing how quickly we lose our perspective on the genra. "House of the Dead", as far as im concerned, is the best, heck, the only, attempt at bringing the gritty, sloppy, rotten, zombie experience of Fulci back to life. Something I thought I'd never see playing at my local cineplex.Don't believe me? Well maybe I should give you some perspective. I told myself a long time ago that I wasn't going to complain anymore about "Scream" and wave of films passing themselves off as horror through the late 90's, since that genra has pretty much died out now, and that by doing so I was really starting to sound like one of those Fangoria dweebs. But honestly, what would you rather sit through when you go to the movies? "Valentine" or "House of the Dead?" "Urban Legends" or "House of the Dead?" "I know what you did last summer" or "House of the Dead?"Yea, I thought so.

House of the Dead is based on the Sega game of the same name. I have never played the game myself but this movie doesn't do very much in the way of persuading one to give it a chance. The story is as follows. A group sets out to go to a Rave party on an isolated island and in their first but not last act of stupidity during the course of the film they miss the boat that was to take them. They coax a cigar smuggling boat owner to give them a ride to the island by giving him $1000. 500 to get there and 500 to get back. With all that cash floating around, the group should have skipped the Rave and went and brought some brains. Well, they get to the island and to sum the rest of the film up, there is a lot of running around, screaming, breasts jiggling, tired and I do mean tired stereotypes of every character, especially the Asian character. That was just ridiculous. Uwe Boll must think that the Matrix is the greatest movie of all time because he uses the camera tricks from that film all throughout the battle sequences, which mind you dragged on way too long. And if all of that wasn't bad enough, Uwe Boll has spliced actual game-play action into the movie. He seemed to think it added to the film, even if the scenes from the game didn't always match up with the live action. I don't even have to mention awful dialog and acting because I can forgive those nuances. They can almost be so bad they're entertaining, but some things I just can't forgive. How Uwe Boll ever got anyone to support him in this film is beyond my comprehension.3/10 Don't waste your time. I'd recommend it to hardcore B movie fans like myself. But if you don't appreciate making fun of movies then don't submit yourself to this torture.

reviews.review_title: Not so bad, But "Jar-Jar" factor needs toned down
reviews.content: Okay, The best way to enjoy HotD is to get in touch with your inner ten year old child.  If you can't enjoy Cheesy B flicks like that, then don't go. If you're the kind who quotes the "Romero Bible", don't go.  Zombies aren't limited by rules, only the limits of your imagination. As corny as you might find that, it may be the best way to enjoy this very flawed movie.  HotD is, at best, a Roger Corman/Sci-Fi channel type of film. Bad cheese, but I've seen worse. Best reason to watch: Jurgen Prochnow and Ellie Cornell.  They have the most dignified characters, the most common sense, and the best lines.  They also have the best death scenes (If you're into that kind of critiquing) Kira, Will and Ona really try, but the script fails them and the other cast members The music wasn't so bad, and the action scenes kicked butt.  I can tolerate the arcade stuff added in.  It's not that annoying if you simply accept this as an Arcade action flick and not a horror film.  I wanted to see the gang kick zombie butt, and I got my money's worth.Worst elements:  The script dialogue.  Ellie and Jurgen get the best lines. Otherwise, there is not an ounce of wit or clever banter. Rudy is the worst Hero since Stephen Dorff's cop from "Fear Dot Com" and Jared Leto's Paul from "Urban Legends".  Casper and Kirk SHOULD have been the main characters since they at least TRIED to save everybody, while Rudy just stares at his current girlfriend getting ripped to shreds. Sloppy editing.  Stupid teen antics. BIGGEST mistake in the whole film is to have Rudy open the movie with the lines "If they hadn't come, they'd still be alive".  This has killed any suspense of seeing who survives in the end! I don't think it's a terrible film, despite my comments.  It's a Cheesy B flick, nothing more.  But I do HOPE that Uwe Boll and Mark Altman LEARN from these flaws.  A sequal is in the planning stages, which may be better than the first if they write and shoot a more clever script

There isn't one horror movie out there that leaves me laughing and shaking in my seat more than House of the Dead had. After watching this last night on DVD, I'm still not sure whether I would give this movie a nod of the head or deface the cover and use the disc as a coaster.To summarise what would be my review for House of the Dead, it would be along the lines of "cheesy goodness" as that what it exactly is: oozing with cheese that makes it good.After having played the game in the arcades, I was happy to have seen it on the new release shelf of my Blockbuster. The title alone was enough to have the case stand out; the cover-art was exceptional; "From Sega's best selling video game" the blurb cried out to me; I was sold.House of the Dead is very disappointing in the sense that it has absolutely no storyline, no character development, no atmosphere and anything else that would make a horror movie a GOOD, at the least, horror movie. The real downside to this movie is that the ending is shown right at the beginning and it is only the process of their elimination that, I guess..., you'd want to stick around. Another would be the fact that the pace of the movie was ridiculously fast that there's no time to make a connection with the characters, let alone know who's who, and at the same time, know what on earth is going on. There is no sense of "survival horror" that one has appreciated in the likeness of the Resident Evil game (or movie), 28 Days Later, Living Dead Trilogy, and such which truly ruined the atmosphere. The ultimately low point of the movie was the middle where the 8 or so "strong" group make for the "House of the Dead", armed to the teeth with guns tuned in to "kick ass" mode, but takes an unnecessarily long time to walk 10-20 meters, even if they were killing the undead in the process. During the course of this action, there were also Matrix-like shots that, I guess because of the quality of the movie, cannot go unappreciated. Yet, there are just so many weakness in the plot, like holding a rave in an island aptly named "Isla de Muerte" (or something) and not finding or sensing anything strange when they arrive at the ransacked and abandoned party. If Spiderman happened to have swung past there, he'd be in a coma because of his spider senses going haywire.Through the course of the movie, I desperately searched for the things to justify the movie's state and to why the actors oozed cheese from every hole in their body. I came to the conclusion that perhaps it was because the game characters of the "House of the Dead" game had the same cheesy voice acting. I guess they had that point and the shootings of the creatures (which was House of the Dead game-like), as well as the "death" scenes similarities down pat. Also, it is good that Sega doesn't go uncredited in the movie and I feel that Uwe Boll, as awkward as he did it, displays this appreciation. However, I guess that by the middle of the movie, you'll realize that this movie cannot be saved from the depths of "F-movie hell" that this had descended to.In the end, with more funding, I think this movie could've been in a "C-movie hell". Different actors who felt the part and more insight into the story could've drastically changed the atmosphere of this movie. As soon as that black chick drop-kicks a downed zombie, you can't help but just start laughing at the attempts of this movie to be cool. It's so excruciatingly stupid, it's entertainingly good, yet I still find it difficult to say that this movie absolutely sucked or good for a really boring day. Perhaps, it is only for the die-hard fans of the game. On a final note, I do appreciate one character comparing the situation to the Living Dead Trilogy, claiming it to be "The Holy Trilogy".

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as the reviews say
reviews.content: I've seen this movie several times. Once or twice when it came out, and then occasionally over the years, as I got a used copy on dvd at some point. All the hype on this movie being "the worst movie ever made" is completely uncalled for. I've seen SO MANY far worse movies than this. Just go into it knowing it's a movie based on a sega arcade game. The only way it could have been made better is if they changed everything about it. And not made it in the early 2000's. This was peak "dumb party horror". Also could have done without some of the bizarre editing choices, but again, early 2000's, post matrix, video game movie. This is an average not great movie. Not the worst.

reviews.review_title: 3 Bad Things, 1 Good Thing about... Uwe Boll's House of the Dead.
reviews.content: ONE BAD THING: This movie has the notable distinction of being truly awful. Uwe Boll firmly establishes his legacy as the worst film maker since Ed Wood. If you don't believe me, do a web search on his name and look for the petitions to force him to stop working.ANOTHER BAD THING: This movie is so poorly conceived and executed that it not only notoriously splices clips of the original video game source material into the live action footage, but also accidentally reveals the device used to launch actors during an explosion made famous by the "A-Team."EVEN ANOTHER BAD THING: This flick gives zombies a bad name. By relying on the undead as nothing more than monster targets for shotgun blasts, the movie never delves into issues of mindlessness and animal-like behavior explored by better film makers (see: "Dawn of the Dead" or "28 Days/Weeks Later").ONE GOOD THING: Featuring perennial horror favorites Jurgen Prochnow and Clint Howard; as well as, atrocious dialog and attractive women in revealing situations, the movie is ripe for drinking games and "Mystery Science Theater 3000" type commentary.OVERALL GRADE: FBETTER MOVIES LIKE IT: Evil Dead II (1987), Army of Darkness (1992), Dawn of the Dead (1998 & 2004), Braindead (1992), Night of the Living Dead (1968), 28 Days Later (2002), 28 Weeks Later (2007).

reviews.review_title: Believe the Hype, it is THAT bad...
reviews.content: On my first chance to watch this infamous movie, I honestly can say that I was not expecting mistakes of this degree in a movie of this budget. It is as if they had given a good budget to a complete amateur. In fact, the entire film-making is completely the opposite to the one Boll displayed in his previous movie "Hearts of America" (2003). The only thing that could explain this serious mess is if Boll believes that his target audience is hungry for pointless and dumb scary movies. I hate to say it, but this movie is that: pointless and utterly stupid.Loosely based on the popular video game, the movie tells the story of a group of teenagers who are going to a rave in an island, only to find that in the middle of the party, a group of strange people appeared and killed everyone. They will discover that the strange people who murdered the ravers is not really alive.Even when the plot of the movie has nothing to do with the video game (only the fact that in both appear the Zombies), the basic idea had potential for being an average horror flick; but the script completely ruins every chance it has for being original and interesting by throwing in a series unrealistic situations that serve the only purpose of moving to the action scenes. This leads to a poor development of both the characters and the plot, as if writers Dave Parker and Mark Altaman were more concerned in getting quickly into flashy action sequences, cheap jump scares and pointless nudity.The direction by Uwe Boll does nothing to save the mess this movie is, and even shows a talent to make the already bad written movie even worse. Not only displays a shaky hand-held camera work that makes it look amateurish, the poor edition and the quick cuts make the movie look like a lame MTV video.I must recognize that Boll certainly had good intentions. The infamous use of footage from the video game could had been a well received idea by the fans of the video game, but his overuse of that resource gets tiresome and annoying specially if we consider that the footage has nothing to do with the scenes. Also, the bullet-time effect is well-used in a few occasions, but in the climatic battle for survival it ends up so repetitive that also ends up as a silly attempt for being innovative.The acting is among the worst, not only because of the poor casting of young adults as teenagers; most of the time they look as if they had no idea of what they were supposed to do. Nevertheless, I must say that the few stars I'm giving to this are because of Jürgen Prochnow's performance. He retains some dignity and his character is the only one that is realistic and well played.Overall, this movie is another good story wasted that will disappoint the fans of the video game. 2/10

Shame on you Uwe Boll! Shame on you for turning what could have been a promising game francise into a total modern day "Monster a Go-Go" film. I mean, this film is soooooo bad, that it made previous based on video game movies like "Final Fantasy", "Street Fighter" and "Double Dragon" look like Oscar winning titles, and that is not saying much either.Here is the "plot":A band of college fraternity/sorrority students go to a rave dance house on a mysterious island and get more than they bargained for when they find themselves stalked by the living dead and evil creatures intent on feasting on the flesh of the living. With only a few weapons and time running out, they take shelter in an ancient house, inside which they will uncover the secrets of the 'House of the Dead.'Bad CG, bad plot, cheese acting and annoying editing. The "zombies" really look like students from some "Special-Ed classes" being initiated and hazed by being forced to star in a bad movie. Oh, and did I mention that Ron Howard's horse faced freak brother, Clint, was in this film? Another reason for major suckage!Oh lord, Uwe Boll, his cronies and producer Warren Zide bought the rights to a "BloodRayne" and "Soul Calibur" movies in making. Please, stop this mad man. Stop him from making more moldy cheese films.

OK lets see how to put this. ABSOLUTELY SUCKED. this is one if not the WORST HORROR MOVIE EVER this movie sucked so unbelievably bad its wasn't even funny to watch. Absolutely the worst cheesy acting not to mention the worst make up ever put on film.( note to the director Walmart doesn't make good Halloween makeup seem scary sorry) The only Thing scary about this movie is how anyone good sit through this entirely. How could the director be so stupid not to notice how crappy this movie is. First off in the zombie scenes u can see normal people just walking around in the background not to mention when the actors walk by a zombie he actually moves his arm so they didn't step on him. WOW THIS MOVIE SUCKED SUCKED SUCKED. And how come in the big scene before the house the house is like 20 feet from them but its more like 20 minutes just for them to get there what did they do walk around in circles???? Uwe Boll is a pure idiot. He does look like a retard as well just look at his face. I could make movies a lot better than all of his. This movie sucked incredibly I can't believe they sell movies like that on the market.The whole movie didn't make any sense. The acting is very bad, the soundtrack is as well but the story is the worst.The only scenes that got my attention was the ones where you could see tits lmao.Ridiculous, disappointing, boring.They should do something useful with their money.

House of the Dead is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. I didn't finish the movie because I couldn't sit through it any more. The acting sucks the characters are stupid, the only thing that was OK was the music. I would not make someone I hate watch this movie, it's just so boring. reviews.review_title: True to the spirit of the source material
reviews.content: I first just wanna say the standards people had for this movie amaze me considering the source material. The House of the Dead games are widely considered having of the worst acting found in any video game series period. The House of the Dead games were rail-gun shooters, where you would shoot lot's of zombies with bits of plot about. They were amazing, but their story bits were also shamelessly (intentionally?) poorly done.This film is actually pretty entetaining as a weirdo horror film goes. The acting is bad, but that's okay because it's campy, and the action is over-the-top but well-shot. The story is cheesy, but that's on par with the source material.Just look at this way. If they made a truly good film based off the House of the Dead games, it would be a bad adaptation. Go on Youtube.com and look up video-footage of House of the Dead 2. I swear that the actors are foreigners reading transliterations!

reviews.review_title: Now this is a video game movie!!!
reviews.content: House of the Dead (2003)is what Resident Evil should have been. A cheesy b-movie filled with bad dialog, bad actors and gory special effects. I can't express how much love I have for this flick. I thought the movie was going to be like Wrong Turn (yuk!) but boy was I wrong. How can you not love Clint Howard or the cigar chomping old salt of a captain Jurgen Prochow. Everything was perfect for this movie, the dialog (bad) the acting (wretched)the music (loud) and it had HEAD SHOTS!! The only thing that bothered me was that the rave was sponsored by "SEGA"?! I never heard of a corporate sponsored rave. Oh well. I bet the director had this on his mind when he made the movie (I have a lousy script, a low budget and some bad actors. Hell, I'll make one of the cheesiest b-movies ever based on a video game!). I have to say he succeeded.Highly recommended!

reviews.review_title: It Could've Been Worse... Not Much Though.
reviews.content: "House of the Dead" is a boring, unoriginal, all around bad horror movie. The plot (if it can be called that) consists of some 20-something year olds, who are going to the "Rave of the century" on some island. After missing the main boat, they get an old fisherman to give them a ride for $1000. Well, the rave is surely no "Rave of the century", it consists of a small stage, some porta potties, and a couple tents. Wow. That's one great rave. A thousand bucks well spent. Anyways, the kids arrive there, find blood splattered all over the rave, nobody there. What do they do? Of course, they go to find all of the partiers, assuming that it was all a big prank. Well, of course they are wrong, and they hole up in a small tomb-like house (that is about 20 times bigger on the inside than it appears from the outside) and fight the zombies to save their lives.I was plain out bored with this movie. The director added a bunch of ridiculous shots from the actual video game the film was inspired by, why? I have no idea, but it looked terrible. The acting was boring and unconvincing, and the writing. Oh, the writing! What kind of person would go look for the "rave" after they arrive there and find the place to be splattered with blood. How likely is it that the entire rave wanted to play a big joke like that? This made me automatically hate the characters. And as they died off, we even got this cheesy still-shot of the camera revolving around them, and the screen fading to red. The person died, we get it, you don't have to include this little farewell.Overall, "House of the Dead" is boring. It's unoriginal, badly acted, and nothing we haven't seen before. I think I'll give it one extra point for the semi-good zombie gore, but other than that, avoid this movie. 2/10.

reviews.review_title: Yes, this is a really bad movie
reviews.content: Yes, this is a really bad movie. I suppose its real intent was to promote the video game, rather than stand on its own. The inter-cut shots from the game are jarring, and add nothing to the movie. But, then again, I'm not a gamer. The girls were cute, at least, and the one actor anyone had ever heard of, Jurgen Prochnow, was big-time slumming. His career must be over. As usual, in films like this, there were huge plot holes and outrageous continuity breaks. And, it seemed to me, the zombies in this film were awfully agile. Reminiscent of "28 Days Later" but those weren't really zombies. These re-animated corpses ran, jumped, swam, and even used weapons. What must George Romero, or your average Haitian, think? I'd have to recommend that everyone should run away screaming from the prospect of sitting through this movie.

First of all, let me say that I went into this with low expectations. It's Uwe Boll, whose films I have always avoided due to friends (who generally understand my tastes in film) warning me away. I've seen a good many zombie films, both good and bad -- most bad -- and the art of making a decent one in this day and age seems to be a lost art, even for past masters of the genre.I will start off by saying that the film has its good elements. It moves quickly, there is a great deal of action, and there were also several scenes that were framed so as to be an homage of sorts to the games upon which the film is based. That was nice, since so many game-to-movies seem to forget their origins, which is unfortunate and frustrating.Just as unfortunately, the history of film is littered with poor game-to-film transitions; most of them can't seem to decide whether they want to try and retain the feel of the games, or try to appeal to a broad audience that may not be familiar with them. The first option tends to fail since if it's too faithful, it's like watching someone else (usually someone not very good) play a game that you like to play, but not necessarily watch. The second also tends to fail since it usually alienates the audience who would have supported the film's release and relies on the general audience to pick up the slack...which is unrealistic since the tie-in with the game wouldn't draw them in anyway.This film is somewhere completely different. It tries to be faithful in feel to the games, but it also tries to be something distinctly different. It doesn't really succeed at either, unfortunately.The biggest problem with this film is that it's not sure whether it wants to be a horror movie, a comedy, or an action film. Combinations of genre are generally volatile and tend to be 'like them or hate them' titles. The most vexing aspect of this combination is the way it plays up some of its characters after a point, makes them impressive and more enjoyable, and then casually knocks off 9/10ths of them in underwhelming sequences that simply disappoint. There are some references and quips that attempt to be witty, but most of them fall flat. It's not a funny film, and horror comedy fusions tend to be mostly one with a smattering of the other anyway.The most interesting and likable characters are shuffled off quickly and nonsensically. The script features a lot of incoherency and completely illogical, unreasonable acts that no-one in any circumstances would ever do, simply for the purpose of thinning out the cast. That always annoys me, and this was no exception. The film was exceptionally frustrating due to that aspect, and I found it impossible after a point to care much about it.It also pulled the unforgivable act of needlessly and ridiculously killing off characters too close to the end after already committing to their impressiveness and logical survival, followed by a completely underwhelming ending that elicited more groans than fanboy tingles. Although I was irritated and put off the film by its earlier antics of thinning out the cast needlessly and nonsensically, pulling the same stunts within the last ten minutes is simply inexcusable.The film could probably be enjoyed if you're drunk, watching with friends who like to poke fun at bad films, or simply don't turn your mind on at all during it. A lot of things happen, explosions, silly effects, flashy shots...that's pretty much it. It has a vague, tenuous link to the video game series of its origins, although it does incorporate some clips and some shots of homage in interesting ways. The rest of it is pretty much generic action fodder, however, and it's not really worth the time.The direction is barely adequate, and it's easy to see that some of the actors are more capable than they're being directed to be. It's especially obvious in the cases of well-known actors on the cast, immensely talented and capable as seen in other works, being directed into more stilted, awkward deliveries. It's unfortunate, and I'm sure some of them were treated poorly for having been involved in this film, but it's really not their faults.It's just an unsuccessful attempt to combine several genres, with a greater budget than it knew how to use, unfortunately. If only a wiser crew had been able to tackle it, it might have turned out much better.

You have to hand it to perpetually-deluded director Uwe Boll (who also graced us with "Alone in the Dark" and "Bloodrayne"): he has a certain sense of style...problem is, it's ingratiatingly inept every step of the way.In "House of the Dead," his translation of a popular Sega game (see the banner?), a bunch of youthful fools (all looking like rejects from "The O.C.") accost ship captain Jurgen ("I was in 'Das Boot'!") Prochnow and crusty first mate Clint ("This is my best role since 'The Wraith'!") Howard to dance the night away at a rave on a secluded island. Once our fools arrive, the place is deserted. Zombies attack. Bullets are fired. Quick edits are employed. What little plot there is is forgotten as events move with a notable lack of logic (they hole up in the 'house,' run back to the boat, then run back to the 'house' again?).With a script this awful, one can hardly blame Boll for doing endless slo-mo and 360-degree freeze frames...trouble is, this comes off as the MTV filler it is, and gets old after the first 2 or 3 times. Ditto the intrusive, random screen shots from the actual video game spliced in with the live action. As for the acting, the 'name' performers convey the whole bill-paying nature of the enterprise, while the 'no names' stumble through scenes with pitiable awkwardness (what is with that moron kicking a DOA ghoul?). The zombie makeup ranges from 'not bad' to 'pretty silly,' and the violence is so exaggerated it ventures into camp (though this certainly ain't no "Dead Alive"). And the "Matrix"-style gunshots are just SO 1999, man...Ultimately, what's strange about "House of the Dead" is that it isn't the worst movie I've seen--in fact, the negative word-of-mouth is what drew me to it in the first place. Is it a 'good' movie? No, not by a long shot. But it isn't necessarily rock-bottom awful, either. While Boll is too slick and kinetic with his camera to draw favorable comparisons to the humbler Ed Wood, his films do leave a slimy, ectoplasmic residue that fascinates (in a morbid, 'how-much-worse-can-it-get' way)...Side note: How in the world did George Romero and Tom Savini wind up in the behind-the-scenes featurette? I'm not complaining...though outdated (with Romero pontificating on what would become "Land of the Dead"), their presence is certainly the high point of the DVD package (watch/listen for a moment where the line, "the success of films like 'House of the Dead'" seems DUBBED IN to Romero's dialog).

reviews.review_title: Molten Metal Poured All Over Your Body
reviews.content: Like getting a vat of molten metal poured all over your body, House of the Dead is a very, very bad, painful experience. The movie starts out like any other cliché horror picture. A terribly acted voice-over tries to explain the main characters, but it's not really stated why they're significant, or where they came from. The guy, Rudy, does mention that one of the characters is his ex-girlfriend, and that she enjoys fencing for no reason at all. This is obviously just a set up to give an explanation to why she can sword fight in a future battle scene. Does writing get any worse than this?. The rest of the movie pretty much takes place on the island. A cut to the island shows pre zombie ravers drinking beer, dancing, and doing' the dirty. I think it also goes without saying that there is, of course, shameless random nudity galore.The camera angles are terrible as well. Cut-aways are used almost every minute, and I could've sworn I saw the same shot of running zombies thirteen times. I really think the director had a thing for slow-motion crab shots too. Pretty much every shot in the action sequences featured a character in the middle of the shot while the camera spun around them "Matrix style".The music wasn't anything special, as it was mostly mainstream rock music blared throughout every fight scene and underlayed with repetitive gunshots. The picture quality was also sub-par. It varied from Panavision niceness, to grainy, blurry, and over-exposed ugliness.Is there anything good about it all? Well, let's see...it's in focus but even then it might have been enjoyable out of focus so we would not see what was going on. So on a scale from 1 to 10, 1 being awful and 10 being great I give House of the Dead a 1.

This movie goes low from the start..but actually goes lower from the moment the teenagers set foot on that island...come on...that's got to have some plot...The director's imagination goes bad when he starts showing those VG scenes of shooting..how can we trust or fear now???

reviews.review_title: What's with all the crap reviews?
reviews.content: Good lord, people, get over yourselves!I think some people watch Uwe Boll films just so they can write bad reviews...which is beyond stupid.If you think it's going to be so bad and such a waste of time...don't watch his films.This film is slick and stylish and actually enjoyable if you watch it for what it is.A previous review stated that since Horror became big business, people expect too much over a, ridiculous to begin with, genre.The acting is not great, but obviously anyone who thinks THIS film is so bad, doesn't watch a lot of zombie movies because, believe me ...there's SO much worse out there.Get a group together, have a pizza and beer party, and enjoy this film for what it is...good fun and some pretty bad a** music!

reviews.review_title: don't waste your time or your money
reviews.content: there is nothing about this movie that is good at all.this is a straight to video movie that somehow made it to the theaters.they try to do this matrix type effects in one part and it looks so retarded.don't waste your time or money on this crap.watch 28 days later instead.

Imagine a group of adolescent geeks decided to make a movie "inspired" by their favorite video game. Then imagine that they secured financing by agreeing to turn their epic into a 90 minute commercial for the game.We know we're in trouble when a giant SEGA banner fills the frame early on in what passes for "the story." But the stomach chunks don't really start blowing until the action intensifies and -- shazaam! -- we are blasted by the editor from the derivatively staged cinematic action directly into snippets of the video game. It occurred to me halfway through this stinker that it was about as much fun as watching a couple of friends play a video game. But minutes later I realized that it wasn't even that much fun. In this case, the player is the director, and his directorial choices stank like baked ass.The writers deserve their share of the credit as well. To say the characters are one dimensional would be generous. My guess is that no one involved in this movie had ever seen a horror movie, let alone could pass as a fan. It has all the hallmarks of pretension one could expect from creators who are slumming in the genre.There is one bright moment early on, when a nubile beauty takes a topless swim. For one teasing moment it seems that we're about to be thrust into a retro horrorsploitation flick, the kind of no holds barred teen hormone catalyzer they used to make before "Scream" laid the future foundation for a kinder, gentler, more pc kind of horror flick.But that moment passes quickly, and the mess that follows is a chore to endure. The zombies are as uninteresting as the rest of the cast. (Note to Jurgen: get a new agent! Fast!) The "kids" in this movie run the full gamut from underacting to overacting. In their defense, it's probable that the producers and director were following an agenda to target this movie to ten-year-old game fans, so any acting which might have led to actual scares or suspense was probably actively squelched.Clint Howard in Gorton Fisherman drag stands out. As demented and lopsidedly comedic as his character is, at least there's a spark of life in him.The zombies attack. Guns start blazing. The soundtrack kicks in with what can only be tagged "trance hop." Too leaden and simple-minded to be trip hop, it amps up the monotony factor tenfold. When the editor isn't lopping in ill-advised bits of pixelated game action, the director is injecting slow-motion whirly-whirl nuggets which instantly remind the viewer that the Matrix did it first, and did it in a much smarter context.If you're tempted to rent this, pick up "House of 1000 Corpses" instead. Even if you've already seen it.

reviews.review_title: The worst horror movie of all time
reviews.content: Oh my god,after i saw this low budget horror flick, i couldn't belive what i just saw, this was really bad. I saw a lot of horror movies, but none of them were so bad like this one. The acting, the dialouges, the sets, everything in this movie was bad. The Zombies looked very crappy, like the ones in "ghost of mars".1/2* out of 10The game was bad , so why did they made a movie too ?Wing Commander was a reason , but a bad movie too.

I have never felt the urge to register and post a comment on a movie in my life but this was ended after my first viewing of house of the dead.The movie is terrible in all ways in fact you will be hard done to find anything good about it and its a sad shame as it could have been good if it was done right. I am still puzzled why after the first water shoot out at the shore they didn't leave the island at that point. i liked the flashback sequence as it condensed the film to a reasonable length. Please anyone thinking of watching this on the big screen do not bother wait for it to appear in the bargain bucket in the local video store.

This is one of the lowest rated movies on the site and its earned. No positives.But, contrary to what I read in some of these reviews here, I laughed a lot at this movie (repeat: AT IT, not with it). To us, its so bad its good, no doubt.

I can't believe this movie is still at a 3 star rating when I wrote this. Have some people gone crazy.  SPOILERS inside:This movie is a piece of crap.  There are so many flaws that I can not name them all.  What was with putting snap shots of the real game throughout the film?  Also when they are fighting zombies to get to the house a few of them have some shots close up then do some camera work around them but while doing this their weapons change and then go back to what they were carrying which proves the shots were of course taken at different times and not flowing.  If you like boobs this was a good movie b/c for the first 20 minutes that is all there is.  The acting was not good at all and I don't even know if I could give it a B movie rating on that.
I hate this movie and will not watch again.  They even set it up for a sequal but why?  Nothing can save this movie.

I rented this movie expecting it to be bad but even I was shocked at how bad it was. On top of the supremely idiotic premise of people gathering on a secluded island (a secluded island with a 'haunted' tag on it) for a rave, the script sounded as if it were written by a bunch of 10-year-olds. The little flashback to explain why the zombies were there was weak, at best, and all of the action sequences made no sense. The only (and I do mean ONLY) part of the movie I enjoyed was when the group was running up to the house and shooting their way through the hordes of zombies (many of them, like all those martial arts films, waiting until one zombie gets shot before attacking) - the Matrix-like filming was pretty cool, except the whole thing only works as a music video. Logically (and I mean horror movie logic), none of it meant any sense. Jurgen Prochnow, an actor of some merit, must have needed the money real bad. This deserves to be on the Bottom #100, no doubt about it.

I actually bought the DVD in a used bookstore for a few bucks. Now that I think about it, I should have saved that money.This movie was horrible. That's all I really have to say. It wasn't bad in a "funny" sort of way. It was just bad.At the beginning of the movie, one of the main characters tells you that all his friends die by the end of the movie. This annoyed me off a lot. This was supposed to be a horror movie, and I didn't want to know that everyone died except him.The characters were flat and static, the acting and script was horrible. Some lines were so cheesy I couldn't bear it.The portrayal of teenagers in this movie was a joke. But it wasn't even a funny joke, because this movie has no redeeming qualities. Even the action begins to get flat boring.But the worst part of this movie was the random screen-shots of the video game at random intervals into the movie.This was a bad movie. If you haven't seen it, don't.

reviews.review_title: Oh man, this sucks, this sucks hard
reviews.content: Uwe Boll has come to be known as the worst director in Hollywood. The new Ed Wood, the all time supreme master of crap. This film has mediocre action sequences that make no sense and copy other films, it has nothing to do with the famous arcade game, and agent G is apparently a black guy. Uwe Boll you are terrible and you really had a cornucopia of things hand wrapped and given out to you, but you had to do it your way didn't you? But I still cannot get over how terrifically mental it is to not have G and Rogan be main characters. Instead you had to take a bunch of idiot teenagers that we aren't attached because they are so unlikable, and then you screw up the race of which G is. YOU COULDN'T EVEN GET THAT TINY LITTLE PART RIGHT! This was a golden opportunity to expand the HOTD universe and add on to the classic game. It was a chance to make thousands of HOTD fans become proud that there favorite game series was picking up and expanding more. But this is just a smear of trash, making sega curse the day they made the game and making people curse the day they ever picked up one of the classic arcade guns. This film blows. Bad dialogue, scenes, acting, editing, and most of all directing.

reviews.review_title: Makes Resident Evil look like a work of art.
reviews.content: Hopefully, Land of the Dead will blow all the bad zombie movies from our memories. It wouldn't have to be very good to beat this movie. House of the Dead rots thanks to bad actors and a horrible director. The scene where the survivors blast their way into the house fully displays this director's vision. We get a three hundred sixty degree shot OF EVERY PERSON firing their gun. Also, I noticed that two of the girls traded guns for their circle, but had their original guns in other shots. Bif Naked is in one shot as a DJ. Clint Howard stars as crotchety fisherman in I Hope You Give Me a Large Paycheck This Summer. Jurgen Prochnow portrays Captain Kirk. Where is a drum set when you need one? Stupid looking zombies, bad special effects, one dimensional characters, and little fun means that this easily wins a spot on the bottom one hundred.

Yeah, this is kind of a lumbering pus pile, but I liked it. It's got a budget, but it is only evidenced by the fact that it's in focus, consistently. It's a real basic Zombie movie, 1/2 "City Of The Dead", 1/2 "Zombie", plotwise, but when is that important in this sort of thing? The visual approach is stupidly inventive with the use of video-game sequences (this can't have been on the burner since the game was popular!?), and crudely derivative for it's fake "Matrix" sequences. Lots of shooting, without much effect, accompanied by similarly useless grunting. The acting is really no worse than we should expect, Clint Howard & Jurgen Prochnow are fun to watch (Prochnow looks like he's trying to channel Robert Shaw, from "Jaws"), and, though the gore might be a little light, it delivers what it promises. Great soundtrack is like a "Sound-Alike" record, with low-rent musicians trying to imitate more familiar songs, without paying copyright fees. The whole movie's kind of like that too, but it manages to achieve it's modest aims, a time or two.

The title, really really bad, is an under-statement.  It really sucked, I actually thought about demanding a refund at the theatre.  There isn't much else to say besides that it really really sucked, bad.  I don't recommend anyone ever to watch this movie.

Usually I am very tolerant to movies that entertain, even when the movie get 1-2 stars from movie critics.But, I can tell you in my second sentence, DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE, even if (1) you are very tolerant to crap movie, (2) you like the SEGA Video Games, (3) you have 2 hours to spend for practically doing nothing.It is not only will waste your time, but most important, you will feel very-very-very irritated. This movie really insults your mind.Why? 1. Worst Acting. Before this, I consider Indonesian artists who play local TV series are suck, but now they look much better. 2. There is no character..... I repeat no character. I do not say weak character. All roles seem to have multi-personality. Sometimes so coward, sometime heroic, sometime melancholic... *yuck* 3. Irrational. Again... this *irrational* word is still not enough to show how this movie insulted my mind. A girl who showed that she is very afraid, suddenly can fight like Jet Li, use weapon like Arnold in Commando, and use sword like McLoud in Highlander.I will not write more....... DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE. Definitely 0/10.

House of the Dead is the first of German auteur Uwe Boll's computer game adaptations. The film made money for its investors, pleased Gamers and triggered an inexplicable landslide of contempt from just about everyone else. The level of criticism directed at this film is utterly ridiculous. House of the Dead is not only a good zombie movie but also the most faithful adaptation of a computer game committed to film.The film's storyline is paper thin. A group of annoying college students sail to a remote island for a "rave" dance party. Unfortunately, the island is inhabited by zombies and lots of people get munched. That's it. Personally, I have no problem with this bare bones approach to storytelling. Unlike Romero's zombie trilogy, there is no social commentary and the film is definitely not a parable for current societal woes. Uwe Boll has no hidden agenda; Boll's only aim is to entertain and he succeeds with a roller-coaster ride of non-stop action, gratuitous breast nudity and corny one-liners. There is nothing high brow about this film and for that I am thankful.The most surprising aspect of "House of the Dead" is how close it stays to its source material: Computer graphics blend into the action scenes, several characters spin to signify death - a trademark of the game, at one stage animated blood drips down the screen, the selection of weapons is almost identical and the techno soundtrack could have been lifted directly from the game. The end result is a film that plays more like a computer game. The pacing is relentless and the live action violence is stylised to the point where it resembles animation. I found the film's mixed media approach highly innovative and distinctive. Obviously, I am in the minority.In addition to its highly unusual visual style, the film's other memorable attribute is the zombie action. I'm not sure how zombie fans could fail to be impressed by the non-stop zombie violence. The make-up and special effects are excellent and the set piece outside the "house of the dead" is fantastic. Boll intersperses slow motion with editing that would make John Woo nauseous in order to create a highly original spectacle. The scene where the zombies chase Simon underwater is fun and a nice little nod to Fulci's brilliant "Zombi 2". Uwe Boll's direction can be described with a lot of different adjectives but "boring" is not one of them. The film has an interesting cast, who admittedly have very little to do apart from run and scream. However, it is always nice to see Juergen Prochnow and Will Sanderson makes another notable appearance in an Uwe Boll production.House of the Dead is one of the better zombie films of the past two decades. I couldn't care less if the film plays like a computer game on steroids. At least House of the Dead has the decency not to bother with the pretence that is has something to say. Some may call it low brow trash - I call it entertainment.

reviews.review_title: This is about zombies, death and destruction. Not Art.
reviews.content: I find it curious that this movie is rated so badly. I won't insult your intelligence and tell you it's terrific, but it's a zombie movie based on a shoot-em-up game. What do you expect? As far as Horror-Zombie movies go, it's definitely quite entertaining. The low rating tells me one thing. People who obviously don't like zombie movies still decided to watch it. And then felt the need to comment on it. In a nutshell if you like mindless action, lotsa guns and the odd walking undead being splattered over your screen then it's well worth a watch since it delivers on all accounts. On the other hand, if you are insulted by the idea that dead people can come back to life and teenagers can instantly become martial arts and gun experts, you're probably in the wrong place.

...but sadly little else, thanks to the empty script. Uwe Boll's oft-bashed first US feature is not the train wreck many bandwagon-haters proclaim it to be, though it is certainly no master piece.The movie starts out with a flash back monologue that lets the audience know bad things are afoot (like we couldn't already guess that) and then is off and running with some party scenes on a gorgeous island that concludes with a some skinny dipping carnage (is there any other kind). From there the film introduces most of the primary cast as they attempt to reach the "party of the year" on the island, only to find instead a zombie wasteland.OK, the story pretty much sucks. Forget about the script taking chances, it barely can keep itself afloat with clique characters and some awful dialogue. Fortunately, genre regulars Jurgen (Seventh Sign) Prochnew, Ellie (Halloween 4) Cornell, Jonathan (Final Destination 2) Cherry, and the ever lovable Clint (oh just pick one) Howard are on hand to add the right amount of knowing winks to make things alright.From the production stand point, things are fairly polished given the uber-low budget. Boll is actually able to scratch out some occasionally nifty visual effects to go along with the gobs of creature gore on hand. The zombies themselves are plentiful and damn near every one gets the ever loving hell blow out of them, much to my delight (why else do people watch these things).It does nothing to advance the zombie sub-genre, nor does it effect a quality story, but the over abundance of zombie carnage ought to keep most horror fans happy.6/10

reviews.review_title: "Why did you do all this to become immortal?" "To live forever" Duh!
reviews.content: In three short years, German director Uwe Boll has launched himself from being that nobody who did that school-shooting movie to being the worst director of horror films/video-game adaptations. The man has a reputation. Is it deserved? When I first heard about this film and how bad people said it was, I first had to ask myself: can it really be that bad? When his second game adaptation, "Alone in the Dark" tanked and people said the same thing, I gave in and rented that film. I nearly drank myself blind trying to glean some kind of enjoyment out of that film. Now I've finally broken down and rented the film that started it all. I have not played any of the games Boll adapted, so I'm rating a film, not an adaptation.There's a voice over narration at the start of this film, presumably to serve as a cheap way to give the viewer a sense of foreboding. Then we meet a group of young people met at the waterfront, having just missed their boat to "the party of the century". They wind up getting a ride from a guy named Captain Kirk (played by Jurgen Prochnow, who is way too good for this movie) and his creepy shipmate Salish (Clint Howard, doing the Clint Howard thing). Howard's character has a creepy stare and warns one of the bare breasted "babes" that the island they're heading to is "eeeeevil" and gives her a cross to protect herself with (you can tell he means it because he isn't looking at her chest). This is a cheesy highpoint, but the acting all around is less than great.When they reach the island their party is already deserted. Then, of course, the zombies start to show up. Since Uwe Boll is such an auteur he doesn't waste any time by trying to frighten his audience. No sir, nobody bothered to make the zombies all that scary, or all that visible. Most of the attack scenes are under-lit to the extreme and shown from a distance. So, there goes anything for fans of being frightened or fans of gore. Most of the focus with the zombies is our heroes kicking their butts. This is enhanced by lots of array shots, which were so not overused in "The Matrix" films that they must be fresh here.Some people die, a couple turn zombie, we find out the horrible truth about the zombies in an ugly sepia-tone flashback. Footage from the video game is thrown into various parts of the film, I guess to remind us that this is a video game movie and not just a regular bad movie. Like I said before, I couldn't care less about the source. After I finished the film I immediately watched it again with commentary just so I could hear the excuses they had for it. The commentary proved far more entertaining, mostly because of the instances where his actors questioned Boll's direction, to his face. Nothing he said did anything to really defend what is truly a horrible movie.The reputation is deserved. The film is visually weak, the characters are practically non-existent (I remember them as Girl in America Flag Outfit, Bimbo, That Guy, Dude Who Mentions Romero, Jurgen Prochnow, Clint Howard), the zombies are like most others zombies except more forgettable, the action is unremarkable, and Boll ultimately shows no flare for the craft or art of film-making.
Greatest zombie film to ever be created. Realistic action scenes and brilliant acting. Will definitely not dissapoint!!

I knew that this movie would be worthless before I even stepped in the door. My theory was proven correct every 5 seconds throughout the entire waste of celluloid/time/money/etc.  No redeeming qualities, not even close to being like the video game at all (even though they remind you with "in-game" clips every 2 minutes), and made on what looked like an even lower budget than 28 Days Later, which I actually have a growing respect for after seeing excrement like this movie.

A lighthearted and violence-happy tone is given to this video game turned feature by darkside-loving German director Uwe Boll. Lacking in original dialog and story the film relies instead on the now tired idea of sending up hackneyed slasher film plots. A group of clueless, self indulgent, over-sexed teens have a rave on a deserted island. And guess what? The island is crawling with low budget zombies. These zombies however move incredibly quickly and there's an overwhelming swarm of them. The film is peppered with naked beauties, bullet ballets, a pounding electronic score and some fairly decent martial arts by a cute Asian character named Liberty. And there's one brilliant sequence showing one character's rapidly cut remembrance of the entire evening's happenings. However none of this is enough to completely cover for the lazy script, substandard acting and the not so special effects.

reviews.review_title: A modern day, 1970's style horror movie
reviews.content:
This movie is taking horrible criticism here on the IMDB.  It is really strange to me to read such bad reviews from people who claim to be fans of old fashioned horror.  I read one review that blasted HOTD and the writer wrote, "I was hoping to see something like an old Romero or Fulcci flick." HOTD is definitely not what you would call a "great" movie, but it does succeed in being similar to an old Fulcii style zombie movie.
The bottom line critique for HOTD is, if you liked Fulcii's "ZOMBIE," then you should like this movie.  It really surprised me to see a modern movie done in such an authentic 1970's horror style.  The movie even begins with gratuitous shots of HOT naked girls!  The zombie makeup is VERY 1970. Most of the zombies simply have on white make up.  The best zombies in the movie have a dirty brown latex "skull" mask. They look pretty good.  Those are my favorite style of zombies.  The dialogue and acting is total "camp" style. It is totally laughable.  This of course means that you will either love this movie for its laughable quality, or you will hate it.  I like campy horror movies, so I liked HOTD.  I definitely believe that if HOTD had been released at some point in the 1970's, it would now be a cult classic, not unlike "LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT" or "ZOMBIE" or "THE HILLS HAVE EYES" or dare I say "EVIL DEAD."One characteristic of the movie that definitely departs from the 1970's style is the use of MATRIX style bullet time effects.  It's pretty fun to watch the high tech special effects in the middle of the zombie melet.The big zombie confrontation in the middle of the film is a lot of fun to watch.  This is the part of the movie when our gang is trying to fight their way through a crowd of zombies in the middle of a spooky graveyard to get inside "THE HOUSE."  That scene was a lot of fun to watch, mindless as it was.  It is a battle-royale with zombies exploding and people being torn limb from limb.  The sequence went on much longer than I thought it would! They just keep on fighting and fighting and blood and body parts go flying all over the place.  COOL!This movie is getting slammed in the reviews, and I think that is unfortunate.  The movie feels very much like a low-budget independent horror movie.  So if you like those, you will probably like HOTD.  I think one of the reasons the movie is not well recieved is because people are expecting something more like "RESIDENT EVIL."  If you are going to watch this movie, try not to take it so seriously.  It really reminded me a lot of "ZOMBIE" which I enjoyed, and also "CHILDREN SHOULDN'T PLAY WITH DEAD THINGS."  If you are looking for low budget fun and a zombie halocaustic setting, then you will like this movie...as long as you have a sense of humor about what you are watching!A little word to the other IMDB reviewers:  LIGHTEN UP A LITTLE, GUYS!

It was only reading more about this film that I found it was based on the 1990s light gun arcade game of the same name, I remember seeing it myself in a few bowling alleys, but I mainly watched this to see if it was as terrible as it was meant to be. Basically college students Simon (Tyron Leitso) and Greg (Will Sanderson) are taking a boat to island for a techno rave party, they meet Alicia (Ona Grauer), Karma (Enuka Okuma) and Cynthia (Sonya Salomaa). Victor Kirk (Das Boot's Jürgen Prochnow) and his first mate Salish (Clint Howard, Ron's brother) give them a ride on their boat, police officer Jordan Casper (Halloween 4 and 5's Ellie Cornell) tries to stop them from leaving, as Kirk is a smuggler, they leave anyway, and find that the rave is completely deserted. Soon they realise that a swarm of flesh-eating zombies and monsters have risen from the ground, from the air and from the sea, and are on the rampage attacking all that come in their sights. One bite from them means slowly transforming into one of them, and the only way to kill them is a shot to the head, the remaining survivors try to stay alive in an old house they find, i.e. the House of the Dead, with other survivors Rudy (Final Destination 2's Jonathan Cherry), Liberty (Kira Clavell) and Hugh (Michael Eklund) inside. In the end some good guns and high explosives help them to escape, there is a point when they think its all over and one last attack occurs, but a team of agents take care of the rest and the last two living return home. Also starring Immortals' Steve Byers as Matt and Smallville's Erica Durance as Johanna. To be honest there is almost nothing good I can say about terribly trashy movie that was just trying to cash into the same audience as the same time's Dawn of the Dead remake, Shaun of the Dead and Resident Evil, I admit maybe my attention was caught by some of the bloody deaths. But the mix of predictable action, including snippets from the video game during, and a stupid storyline to act as a "prequel" to the game made this film nearly unbearable to keep up with and care about, a rather rubbish horror thriller. Pretty poor!

reviews.review_title: Walking dead...the life of the party?
reviews.content: Uwe Boll directs this horror flick based on a Sega Dreamcast video game of the same name. Don't expect a lot. You may be creeped out by the graphic gore...but its doubtful you'll find anything scary in the HOUSE OF THE DEAD. Lame acting, half naked teens(maybe twenty-something)and zombies...that's entertainment. Five Seattle friends hire a boat to take them to a nearby island that is the site of a weekend rave. It seems the party has been pooped already and the late arrivals discover how and why...walking dead. Corpses from an island cemetery crash the party and are ready to now eliminate the interlopers. The cast features relative unknowns: Jonathan Cherry, Cynthia Solomaa and Will Sanderson...and some actors you may have noticed before...Jurgen Prochnow, Ellie Cornell and Clint Howard. I admit it is kinda neat watching the zombies explode at the wrong end of some bad ass weapons. Frozen motion camera sequences give you the idea someone did try to make this more than a B minus movie.

reviews.review_title: I got about halfway through it and couldn't wait to eject it!!
reviews.content: Like everybody, I've seen a lot of bad movies.  This one was so bad I asked the clerk at the video store if I could get my money back!  Of course, they don't do that, but I thought I'd ask anyway.  If you like blood, guts and guns with no plot whatsoever, then this one is for you.

I have to call it a bad comedy because it looked like it was comical, but when I hit info on my DirecTV it was telling me that it was a horror. I was more horrified by Finding Nemo. It actually didn't start off all bad, I mean, many scary/horror movies are a bit cheesy with the acting and storyline so that didn't bother me too much. I guess I was most put off by the instant fighting and shooting skills the characters displayed in the face of danger, the relative calm they all exhibited when they had a gun in their hand and were shooting dozens of zombies, the ridiculous camera shots with the freeze framing and panning just to make it look cool. So... I won't give it a 1 because of two reasons 1.) I didn't pay to see it and 2.) I've seen worse.

First and only time I actually walked out of a movie... After probably half of the theater already did... It's not even one of those really really bad movies you just have to watch anyway... It's honestly worse than that...Apparently there is a minimum of 10 lines to write... But I don't know what else to write about this movie... It's absolutely horrible... It's a very very bad movie... That's all there is to it... It's bad bad bad...Still not enough... Horrible movie... Do not watch and especially do not pay for it...

reviews.review_title: STUPIDEST MOVIE I SEEN IN MY LIFE!
reviews.content: This movie was horrid! I could have gone to see something else! The plot was so stupid and the actors were sooo cheesy!! I just wanted to get up and get my money back although I couldnt.  The parts where they show the videogame itself was stupid and annoying!!  The actors needed some acting lessons and whoever wrote the script needs a better editor. It was so funny when someone gotten killed too. I wasnt the only one laughing  everyone else did too. The part where they entered that house they were acting like they were showoffs fighting zombies (big deal). And the stupid part about that was the slow motion matrix type of thing. My point is GO SEE A MOVIE THAT ISNT STUPID AS THIS! IF U PLAN TO SEE THIS DONT!

reviews.review_title: Boll... put down the camera before you hurt... well, more of us
reviews.content: There are bad movies. There are guilty pleasures. There are movies that are so bad, they're good(and a select few that go beyond that, *back* to bad... thank you, Ghost World). But Uwe Boll's movies... this may be the first one I've watched, though I wouldn't exactly brag about having watched more than one, except maybe on account of having that high tolerance. Uwe Boll's movies... just saying it, sort of, you know, bad aftertaste. He seems to largely make movies based on video-games(at what point does "someone's gotta do it" become "... if he's our only option, I can do without it"?), and, while I can agree that that might not be the easiest kind to make(has there been a truly good one yet? They tend to range between "watchable" and... "not"), it would seem that Boll's are extraordinarily poor. The plot is... worse than it had to be. The acting is atrocious. The dialog is awful. The editing and cinematography both seem dead-set on turning the "film" into a music video, and the action... well, you might as well watch someone play the game(at times, it would be *more* entertaining to do so), better yet, play it yourself. The use of footage from the game, all... *32*?(!) of them... uh, yeah, Uwe? Don't. The music... eh. Language is loose, there is some nudity, and plenty of violence/gore. Attempts are made to recreate some of the recognizable images from the game, with reasonable success, I suppose. I recommend this to... fans of... Uwe...? No, that's not it... people looking for horror...? Hm... well, if you've got *nothing* to do for an hour and a half, if it's on or you've borrowed it(so there's no personal cost to you, money-wise), I guess there are worse things to be doing, if that does make for a terribly short list. 1/10

reviews.review_title: I'm not sure what Uwe Boll has against cinematography but ....
reviews.content: I couldn't leave this movie because there were people asleep either side of me and I'm not evil enough to wake them so that they are subjected to a single second more of this motion picture. I would gladly have beaten myself to death with my left arm if I thought I could get it out of the socket without waking people. I felt like one of those guys in the forties who was forced to sit and watch a nuclear explosion from behind a single pane of glass and, like those poor chaps, I believe that there is a pretty good chance that the after-effects of witnessing this film will be with me for years to come. I walked past a movie theatre recently and felt a shudder go down my spine. I haven't been to the cinema since and I'm not sure if I will be able to ever again. Uwe Boll believes he is a genius. He is not. He is waging a war on cinema, ethnically cleansing good character development, dialogue and continuity from the silver screen. He should be brought before a tribunal and locked up indefinitely.

reviews.review_title: "House Of The Dead"- 6/10. Absolutely horrible, but still enjoyable despite it's flaws.
reviews.content: House Of The Dead (2004)This movie begins with this group of friends who get a ride on a boat to an island for a rave. When they arrive there, they find no one and meet up with a cop, Jordan Casper (Ellie Cornell- Halloween 4 & 5), and a group of other people who where at the rave when walking dead zombies murdered everyone, turning them into zombies and multiplying there kind. The group fights the zombies with all the weapons they can (mostly guns), and barricade themselves in a house on the island.This movie has mostly ideas that have been recycled over and over again. It uses  Romero's Night of the Living Dead premise, where the gang is locked inside the house with zombies trying to break in. Director Uwe Boll adds in clips of the video game in between shots to remind us of the film's basis, which is pretty dull if you think about it, but it gives it a bit of a unique edge. The acting is mostly horrible, except for Jonathan Cherry (Final Destination 2, They) and Clint Howard, but the rest of the actors are your basic Friday the 13th stupid teenagers who can't act their way out of a paper bag. The movie serves up a lot of gore, so it makes up for some of it's flaws. I hope to see a bit better from Uwe Boll in his upcoming "Alone In The Dark" film that is, again based on a video game.All in all, the story is overused and getting dull, the acting is mostly terrible, the dialogue is dumb, but it's still one of those movies you can still like for what it is, despite it's flaws. It can be enjoyable, just don't take it seriously. 6/10.

reviews.review_title: Is Uwe Boll Albert Pyun's long lost brother?
reviews.content: After having suffered through three previous Uwe Boll fiascos ("Blackwoods", "Postal" and "In The Name Of The King"), I swore that I would never see another Boll movie, at least if I had to pay for it. This one came on Canadian TV recently, and I have to wonder why the station risked its reputation by showing it. The only reason I can think of is that the movie is a Canadian co-production with Germany, and the TV station may have been desperate to meet its Canadian content quota.I don't know if I can say anything different than any of the other scathing user comments this movie has gotten. Yes, the movie looks as cheap as its $7 million budget. Yes, the movie has a terrible script (someone would spend more than $1000 to get to a pretty underwhelming-looking rave? And several important turns in the plot happen OFFSCREEN.) Yes, the movie cuts in (blurry-looking) clips from the video game for no apparent reason. Yes, the movie is terribly directed (We seldom get a good look at the zombies despite there being dozens of zombies roaming around, and there's simply no feeling of terror coming from the direction or characters.) Yes, this movie is bad, even worse than what you may expect. You'll wonder how someone as incompetent as Boll got his hands on this project, and other projects since. The only possible answer I have to this question is that Germany has some kind of tax shelter plan for film investment that doesn't encourage quality, like what Canada had at one point in the past.

**SPOILERS*** Uwe Boll's outrageous movie about a zombie upraising that was sparked when a group of college students got together on this unknown island for spring break. A number of students who missed being at the rave, party, on the island lead by Alicia, Ona Grauer, get local seaman Captain Kirk, Jurgen Prochnow, together with his first mate hook man Salish (Clint Howard), to take them there for something like $1,000.00 for his services.
